moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 d5: If you want to play the Sicilian,I would advise you to get a book on it, or at least play through a few grandmaster games to get a feel for your particular chosen variation. 3...cxd4 was necessary here.
moves.4. exd5 Qxd5: Getting your queen out this early is usually a bad idea.
moves.5. Nc3: White gains time by attacking the queen.
moves.5... Qe6+: A horrible square for the queen. It makes the development of your bishops more difficult.
moves.8. Kd1: White has forfeited the right to castle, but without the queens on the board, this is not a problem.
moves.8... Bf5: Threatening the c-pawn, but if White plays 9.c3 Black can play ...Nd3, still winning a pawn.
moves.11. Ne5: I'm not sure what White was trying to do here. 11.a3 was the obvious move.
moves.11... cxd4: 11...e6 looks good here. If White plays 12.dxc5, Black has 12...Rd8 .
moves.12. Bxd4 Nxa2 13. Ra1 Be6: Hanging on to the second pawn, but at some cost.
moves.14. Nf4: White's pieces are now dominating the centre, and he threatens to double Black's pawns by capturing his best piece.
